Question: I clearly define my role and expected tasks at the start of the project.
I meet all internal deadlines set by the group.
I use a shared platform (e.g., Google Docs, Trello) to track progress and documents.
I proactively reach out to a group member if they miss a deadline.
I break down large group tasks into smaller, manageable sub-tasks.
I communicate my progress and any roadblocks without being asked.
I listen actively to teammates' suggestions before offering my own.
I provide constructive feedback on others' work, focusing on the project goals.
I promptly respond to group messages or emails (e.g., within 2 hours).
I clearly summarize meeting outcomes and next steps for the group.
I address conflicts or disagreements directly with the involved parties rather than avoiding them.
I hold myself accountable for mistakes and offer solutions to correct them.
I ensure work quality meets high standards before submitting my part to the group.
I am comfortable voicing a dissenting opinion when I believe it benefits the project.
I work to resolve differences by focusing on shared objectives, not personal feelings.
I volunteer for challenging or less desirable tasks.
I proactively offer help to teammates struggling with their assigned tasks.
I introduce new ideas or creative solutions to the group beyond my assigned tasks.
I take initiative to schedule meetings or preparatory work when necessary.
I encourage quieter members to share their thoughts and ideas.
I use a project timeline (Gantt chart or similar) to visualize dependencies and monitor overall progress.
I prioritize high-leverage tasks that move the entire project forward over small, easy tasks.
I clearly estimate the time required for my tasks and communicate changes if the estimate shifts.
I document processes and decisions in a central location accessible to all teammates.
I review the project's **scope and objectives** at least weekly to ensure we stay on track.
I prepare an **agenda** and desired outcomes before every group meeting.
I start working on my assigned tasks immediately instead of procrastinating until the last minute.
I anticipate potential roadblocks (e.g., missing data, technical problems) and communicate them early.
I clearly define the **minimum viable product (MVP)** or expected quality level for each deliverable.
I divide my personal workload efficiently based on my energy levels and peak productivity times.
I use 'parking lot' lists to defer non-critical discussion points until after the main agenda is complete.
I ensure that group meetings end with defined action items assigned to specific individuals.
I dedicate uninterrupted time blocks to work on complex group tasks.
I create and maintain a detailed version history for all core project documents.
I cross-check my completed tasks against the initial assignment criteria to ensure compliance.
I use a shared calendar to display my general availability for meetings and work sessions.
I follow a 'Do-Review-Complete' process before marking a major task finished.
I proactively check the project timeline to identify if the group is falling behind schedule.
I utilize collaboration features (e.g., commenting, tagging) efficiently in shared documents.
I document any significant **changes in project scope** and ensure the group agrees on the implications.
I tailor my communication style to the receiver (e.g., brief summary for busy leaders, detailed explanation for collaborators).
I check for understanding by asking teammates to summarize key points after I explain a complex idea.
I offer praise or positive reinforcement for good work to boost group morale.
I phrase my suggestions as questions (e.g., 'What if we tried X?') to foster open discussion.
I actively seek feedback on my own contributions before submitting them as final.
I am transparent about my personal work limitations or external commitments affecting my time.
I clearly separate **facts** from **assumptions** when discussing project issues.
I use appropriate communication channels (e.g., email for official decisions, chat for quick questions).
I avoid interrupting teammates when they are speaking during meetings.
I make an effort to use inclusive language that is respectful of all group members.
I paraphrase others' ideas to confirm I've grasped their meaning accurately.
I clearly articulate the **'Why'** behind my suggestions or proposed changes.
I maintain professional courtesy and tone, even in moments of high stress or disagreement.
I follow up on unanswered questions or ignored messages to ensure information isn't lost.
I practice **active listening** by putting away distractions (like my phone) during meetings.
I summarize my understanding of complex instructions immediately after receiving them.
I ensure my written communications are clear, concise, and free of grammatical errors.
I use clear headers or bullet points in communications to make information easily scannable.
I clarify vague terms or assumptions made by teammates to ensure alignment.
I communicate potential resource needs (e.g., access to data, specialized software) proactively.
I believe that constructive conflict (disagreement over ideas) leads to better group outcomes.
I ensure that responsibility for a task is clearly **accepted** by a teammate, not just assigned.
I actively propose alternative solutions when criticizing a teammate's work or idea.
I avoid engaging in or listening to group gossip or forming cliques.
I focus on the **behavior/action** when giving critical feedback, not the person's character.
I actively seek to understand the underlying **reason** for a missed deadline or poor performance.
I maintain a record of assignments and who is responsible for each task.
I publicly acknowledge when a teammate points out an error in my work.
I help establish clear ground rules or norms for group interaction at the outset.
I follow through on every commitment I make to the group, no matter how small.
I initiate difficult conversations about performance issues rather than waiting for them to escalate.
I apologize sincerely and quickly when I realize I have made a mistake that affected the group.
I ensure group decisions are documented so that accountability is clear later on.
I am comfortable being challenged on my ideas, seeing it as an attempt to strengthen the project.
I avoid passively agreeing to a workload I know I cannot reasonably manage.
I ensure that the accountability process applies equally to all members, including myself.
I advocate for group members who are being unfairly criticized or overwhelmed.
I clearly state my expectations regarding quality and timeliness to my collaborators.
I focus on addressing the immediate problem and avoid bringing up past grievances during conflict.
I document instances of repeated non-performance before escalating the issue to a supervisor/instructor.
I take the lead in structuring the final presentation or report.
I seek out and integrate **external resources** (e.g., research, case studies) to enrich the project.
I consistently bring a positive, solution-oriented attitude to group meetings.
I actively work to ensure every group member understands their value and contribution.
I offer technical expertise (e.g., formatting, data analysis, graphic design) if it benefits the final product.
I identify and fill knowledge gaps within the group by offering to learn new skills.
I take on the role of 'devil's advocate' to test the weaknesses of the group's core strategy.
I ensure that creative ideas generated by the group are captured and reviewed, not dismissed.
I facilitate brainstorming sessions when the group gets stuck on a problem.
I set small, internal **milestones** to maintain momentum and celebrate small successes.
I proactively look for ways to simplify complex processes for the benefit of the group.
I take the initiative to reach out to external stakeholders (if applicable) for information.
I contribute my fair share of the work and avoid relying on others to pick up my slack.
I focus on finding ways to improve the group's **efficiency** over multiple tasks/projects.
I ensure that our final deliverable is polished and professionally presented.
I actively check in with teammates outside of scheduled meetings to see if they need assistance.
I contribute ideas aimed at improving the *process* of how we work together, not just the *content*.
I manage the team's internal documentation and knowledge base effectively.
I take the lead in ensuring the group is prepared for any formal presentation or defense.
I introduce relevant data or evidence to support my proposed course of action.
I make an effort to recognize and leverage the **strengths** of different group members.
I adapt my working style (e.g., remote vs. in-person, flexible vs. structured) to the needs of the group.
I actively seek to understand the perspectives of teammates whose views differ significantly from mine.
I recognize when a teammate is experiencing stress or burnout and offer support.
I foster a climate of **psychological safety** where others feel comfortable taking risks.
I consciously minimize distractions (e.g., phone use) during group work sessions.
I am empathetic when listening to a teammate explain a personal difficulty or roadblock.
I maintain focus and redirect conversations gently when they drift off-topic.
I ensure that credit for successful outcomes is shared equally among all contributors.
I proactively define our group's **team norms** (e.g., how decisions are made, meeting etiquette).
I check in with quiet or reserved members to make sure their voice is heard.
I try to find common ground or consensus before moving forward with major decisions.
I maintain an optimistic and encouraging tone, especially when the project faces challenges.
I help the group reflect on what worked well and what didn't after a milestone is reached.
I understand and respect the cultural differences or different professional backgrounds of my teammates.
I ensure that group decisions are made through a fair and transparent process.
I use humor appropriately to lighten the mood or ease tension.
I actively build rapport by getting to know my teammates on a personal level (within professional bounds).
I encourage the group to take necessary breaks during long work sessions.
I effectively manage my own emotional reactions when faced with criticism.
I am aware of the non-verbal cues (e.g., frustration, confusion) exhibited by my teammates.
I prioritize the success of the overall team over my individual recognition.
I try to involve all relevant members in decision-making processes.
I define and agree on a clear process for handling emergency situations or unforeseen problems.
I show appreciation for the contributions of others through explicit verbal recognition.
